user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_irq_shutdown:
```c
void metal_linux_irq_shutdown(void)
{
	int ret;

	metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "%s\n", __func__);
	irq_handling_stop = true;
	metal_linux_irq_notify();
	ret = pthread_join(irq_pthread, NULL);
	if (ret) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "Failed to join IRQ thread: %d.\n",
			  ret);
	}
	close(irq_notify_fd);
	metal_mutex_deinit(&irq_lock);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_linux_irq_shutdown:
static int metal_linux_irq_notify(void)
{
	uint64_t val = 1;
	int ret;

	ret = write(irq_notify_fd, &val, sizeof(val));
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s failed\n", __func__);
	}
	return ret;
}
...
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
...
static bool irq_handling_stop
...
static pthread_t irq_pthread
...
static int irq_notify_fd
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I examined the provided code for any use of the standard library function memcmp (the subject of MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14). The presented fragments are:
- metal_linux_irq_shutdown (uses metal_log, sets flags, calls metal_linux_irq_notify, pthread_join, close, metal_mutex_deinit)
- metal_linux_irq_notify (uses write and metal_log)
- metal_log macro (invokes a log handler via _metal.common.log_handler)
- declarations of irq_handling_stop, irq_pthread, irq_notify_fd
None of these fragments call memcmp or perform byte-wise comparisons of null-terminated strings. The only standard-library calls visible are write, pthread_join and close, which are unrelated to memcmp. 

Note: I did not find any memcmp usage in the supplied code. If memcmp is used inside code not provided here (for example inside metal_fmt, the log handler implementation, or other modules), those locations would need to be investigated; but from the supplied fragments there are no occurrences to report.
